III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Facility is an unsafe environment. Youth are physically assaulting
one another and sometimes this includes the use of weapons.
Youth broke into the kitchen in attempt to get knives. On 8/27/24,
male and female youth left a campsite and engaged in sexual
intercourse. They were gone for up to 8 hours without supervision.
Investigation Interviews:
The complainant was anonymous.
Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Director said she is not aware of any
incidents where youth have gotten into the kitchen, got knives and
threatened each other or staff. Director said she is not aware of
youth using rocks as weapons on each other, however, there have
been incidents where youth throw rocks towards staff or property.
Director said there have been several fights between youth at
Clarence Fischer Center and to her knowledge staff always
intervene in the situation and stop the youth from fighting. Director
said she is aware of one “jumping” incident with the youth at
3

Clarence Fischer Center. Director said Youth F was fighting with
Youth E and Staff 3 intervened at which time Youth F grabbed
Staff 3’s wrist and she yelled out in pain due to just recovering
from surgery on the same wrist. Director said as soon as Youth E
heard the yell he got upset along with Youth A, Youth C, and Youth
D who all jumped on Youth F and assaulted him. Director said
Staff 3 and Supervisor Y intervened and stopped the fight.
Director said on August 27, 2024, Youth A, Youth B, Youth C,
Youth D, and Youth E ran out of different units of Clarence Fischer
Center. Director said she is unsure which staff followed the youth,
however eventually they were reported AWOL. Director said staff
resumed searching in the morning where they found the youth in
an empty cabin at camp three which is not licensed.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
30, 2024, by MDHHS worker, and on September 6, 2024, via
phone by DCWL consultant and MDHHS worker. Youth A said
he has been placed at Clarence Fischer Center for about thirty
days and there is no structure, and the youth do “whatever we
want”. Youth A said there have been some fights between youth
“little bit, but not for real”. Youth A said staff always break up any
fights by separating the youth. Youth A denied the staff allowing
youth to fight at any time. Youth A denied knowing any staff or
youth that have been injured by fights. Youth A denied ever using
or seeing other youth using rocks or knives during fights. Youth A
said he has never seen or heard of youth going into the kitchen to
get knives.
Youth A denied every AWOLing for an entire night. Youth A said he
feels safe at Clarence Fischer Center and did not have any
concerns.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 11, 2024. Youth B said he has never seen youth
threaten each other with knives or rocks. Youth B said he has
never seen a group of youth “jump” another youth. Youth B said
he has seen and been a part of fighting other youth. Youth B said
staff always intervene and stop the youth from fighting, denying
staff ever allow the youth to fight.
Youth B said he was one of the youth that AWOLed from the unit
on August 27, 2024. Youth B said he ran out of the unit and went
to the gym with Youth A, denying having any interaction with the
Vassar House youth. Youth B said he left around 5am and was
back on his unit by 6:30am. Youth B said no staff followed him
4

because there were other youth sleeping on the unit. Youth B said
he does not recall which staff were working that night. Youth B
said staff always follow the youth that run off the unit during the
day because there are more staff, and at night they cannot follow
because they have to stay with the youth that are sleeping.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Youth C said he has never heard or seen any
youth break into the kitchen or threatened someone with a knife.
Youth C said he has never seen youth use rocks as a weapon
against staff or other youth. Youth C said there have been
“several” fights at Clarence Fischer Center and staff always
intervene and stop the youth. Youth C said he is aware of one
incident where Youth F was “jumped” by a group of youth. Youth C
said Youth F was fighting with Youth E and grabbed Staff 3’s wrist
when she tried to intervene. Youth C said when Youth F grabbed
Staff 3, she was hurt which made him and the other youth mad, so
they all “jumped” Youth F for “hurting a woman”. Youth C said Staff
3 and Supervisor Y broke it all up and separated the youth.
Youth C said he left his unit on August 27, 2024, late at night and
met up with Vassar House youth. Youth C said staff from his unit
did not follow him due to other youth being left on the unit they
needed to supervise. Youth C said Supervisor Z followed him for a
while but he “lost her”. Youth C said Vassar House staff also were
following him and the Vassar House youth, however eventually
they “lost them” as well. Youth C denied ever threatening any of
the staff. Youth C said he arrived at the cabin and two youth from
Clarence Fischer Center were already inside. Youth C said he
does not know if staff knew they were all in the cabin. Youth C said
he “chilled” there for the night with some Clarence Fischer Center
youth and some Vassar House youth. Youth C said staff found him
the following morning.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
30, 2024, by MDHHS worker, and on September 6, 2024, via
phone by DCWL consultant and MDHHS worker. Youth D
stated there have been daily fights at Clarence Fischer Center
between his unit and one other unit. Youth D denied any rocks or
knives being used stating "we don't got knives". Youth D said he
does not know if they even have knives at the facility and has no
knowledge of any youth trying to get any knives. Youth D said staff
try to break up the fights whenever they occur. Youth D said staff
will try to move the youth away from the fight into another room or
outside. Youth D denied there have been any fights where staff
have not tried to break them up. Youth D said he and other youth
5

have taken the staff “walkies” and will communicate with one
another and the youth from Vassar House on them.
Youth D said he has left the unit on different occasions and run
around campus with other youth. Youth D said sometimes it is just
for an hour or two, another time it was all night long. Youth D said
the staff will call the police, follow them, and tell them to go back to
the unit. Youth D said the night he and other youth were out
overnight the staff had been looking for them but then stopped.
Youth D said Staff 5 was working on his unit but was not able to
follow the youth when they ran out because she was the only one
on the unit with another youth that did not leave. Youth D reported
the staff knew where the youth were, but they "knew we were
gonna run and they couldn't catch us” so they stopped looking.
Youth D said at 8am the following morning the police and staff
came and got them from cabin three.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Youth E said he has never seen any youth
get jumped by a group of other youth. Youth E said he has never
heard of or seen youth break into the kitchen to get knives or
threaten one another with knives. Youth E said he has never seen
or heard of any youth using rocks as weapons against each other
or staff.
Youth E said he did not leave his unit the night of August 27, 2024,
stating he was asleep and did not see anything. Youth E denied
seeing any Vassar House youth enter Clarence Fischer Center.
Youth E said staff have always followed him whenever he has left
the facility. Youth E said things are “great” at Clarence Fischer
Center.
Youth F was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024. Youth F said he has never seen or heard of
youth breaking into the kitchen to get knives and threaten each
other with them. Youth F said he has seen many youth throwing
rocks at windows and doors. Youth F said there was one incident
when Youth E threw a brick at Youth G and Staff 4 intervened,
grabbed the brick and stopped Youth E from assaulting Youth G.
Youth F said he has never seen or heard of staff allowing youth to
fight and any fights he has witnessed staff have always intervened
and stopped the fight. Youth F said he was “jumped” one time by
Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E. Youth F said Youth E came into
his unit and said he was going to beat people up and Youth F
asked who and Youth E said you and “swung” on him. Youth F
said Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E all jumped in and started
6

hitting him and two staff broke up the fight. Youth F said he cannot
remember which staff was present in that incident.
Youth F denied ever AWOLing however said whenever his peers
have left the unit staff have always followed them and called the
police for assistance.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on October 24, 2024.
Staff 1 said he worked at Clarence Fischer Center for about six
months. Staff 1 said there have been several fights between the
youth at the facility over the last few weeks and staff always
intervene and try to separate the youth. Staff 1 said he has stood
in-between youth and at times has gotten hit by youth in the
process. Staff 1 denied the youth fighting with rocks or knives.
Staff 1 denied knowing anything about youth getting into the
kitchen and getting knives.
Staff 1 said he worked the third shift on August 27, 2024. Staff 1
said he was on unit three with four youth. Staff 1 said Youth A and
Youth B were in and out of the unit between 11pm and 6am
however the other two youth stayed on the unit and therefore he
was unable to follow Youth A and Youth B off the unit when they
walked out. Staff 1 said he does not recall who the supervisor
working that night was. Staff 1 said he was given a directive to
stay on his unit and supervise the youth that remained and do his
best to keep track of Youth A and Youth B as they went on/off the
unit and encourage them to remain on the unit whenever they
came back. Staff 1 said when Youth A and Youth B returned to the
unit, he attempted to direct them to stay by using directive
statements, encouraging words, and reminding them that breaking
the rules will not be helpful for their programming. Staff 1 said he
does not know what other staff were working that night however
said he knows someone was following the youth because he was
getting updates on where they had been spotted around campus.
Staff 1 denied anyone asking him to follow the youth around that
night. Staff 1 said whenever the staff are able, they follow any
youth around campus that walk off the unit. Staff 1 said they do
not restrain the youth unless it becomes a safety risk to
themselves or others. Staff 1 said he felt the staff were doing the
best they could with the youth in the program.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on September 25, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 said there are
many fights in Clarence Fischer Center and the staff do everything
they can to break them up however at times it is very difficult and
chaotic due to the number of youths that become involved. Staff 2
7

said there have never been any incidents with knives or rocks
were used as weapons, however she has seen youth throw items
at each other they find in the units such as a glass bottle. Staff 2
said she was involved in an incident on August 16, 2024, where a
group of youth from one unit got onto her unit and all the youth
were fighting one another. Staff 2 said staff were called to help
from other units and they did the best they could, but the youth
were stronger than some of the staff and able to fight each other
for several minutes before they could break it up.
Staff 2 said the youth were walking out of the units and building as
they pleased, and staff followed them wherever they went. Staff 2
said she would bring youth with her to follow the youth that walked
out in order to stay within ratio, as there was no extra staff
working.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on September 30, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 5 said she is aware
of many fights between the youth at Clarence Fischer Center
however has never heard of youth using knives or rocks as
weapons against one another. Staff 5 said staff always intervene
and separate the youth when they fight.
Staff 5 said she was working the night of August 27, 2024, when
Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E ran off her unit with Vassar House
youth. Staff 5 said there was another youth in the unit and so she
was not able to follow them. Staff 5 said she notified Supervisor Z
about the situation and was told to secure the doors and remain in
her unit with the other youth. Staff 5 said there was a Vassar
House staff with the youth when they ran off the unit. Staff 5 said
Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E never returned to the unit while she
was working. Staff 5 said she does not know who went to look for
them or if the police were called. Staff 5 denied Supervisor Z
asking her to switch out due to Supervisor Z’s restrictions, noting
she would not have felt safe being out in the middle of the night
looking for Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E.
Supervisor X was interviewed via telephone on October 10,
2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Supervisor X said
the youth at Clarence Fischer Center were running around as they
pleased for a week or so and the staff would always follow behind
them and encourage them to return to the unit. Supervisor X said
staff would notify her when they ran off via walkie talkie and she
would also follow behind them. Supervisor X said she followed the
Clarence Fischer Center youth over to Vassar House several
times during those weeks.
8

Supervisor Y was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024. Supervisor Y said he was in the conference
room on August 29, 2024, and heard a loud noise so went to
check on what it was. Supervisor Y said he arrived on the unit and
Youth F and Youth E were trying to fight and hit each other a
couple of times before the staff were able to remove Youth F from
the area and into the classroom. Supervisor Y said Staff 3 had
injured her wrist attempting to separate Youth F and Youth E and
five other youth found out about the injured wrist and ran into the
classroom and began to hit Youth F. Supervisor Y said staff were
able to get Youth F out of the classroom and down the hallway
and stood around him to protect him from the other youth.
Supervisor Y said additional staff responded to the situation and to
remove the other youth. Supervisor Y said the staff did everything
they were able to protect Youth F and remove the other youth from
the situation. Supervisor Y said he has been present for other
fights between youth and staff always intervene and do their best
to stop the fights and remove the youth. Supervisor Y said he has
never seen or heard of any youth with knives. Supervisor Y said
serval youth have thrown rocks at the building and cars, but he is
not aware of rocks being used as weapons against other youth.
Supervisor Z was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Supervisor Z said she has never seen or heard of youth getting
into the kitchen and having knifes as weapons in fights.
Supervisor Z said the youth would often pick up rocks or sticks
and threaten to use those as weapons against staff when angry.
Supervisor Z said youth have been fighting more frequently
however it usually is on first or second shift which she does not
work as often. Supervisor Z said anytime she has seen youth
fighting the staff intervene and stop the youth.
Supervisor Z said she was working at Clarence Fischer Center on
third shift on August 27, 2024. Supervisor Z had a difficult time
remembering exact details stating there has been “so much going
on” that she felt a lot of situations blended together. Supervisor Z
said she recalled several youth going in and out of the building “as
they pleased” throughout the evening. Supervisor Z said all of the
units had one staff with four youth and so they were using radios
and cell phones to communicate from unit to unit. Supervisor Z
said she recalled being contacted by Staff 5 when the whole unit
ran out the back door. Supervisor Z said she and Staff 5 followed
the youth around the campus on and off for about three hours,
later stating she was out for thirty minutes and then went back to
9

the facility due to her being on medical restrictions. Supervisor Z
said two staff and two supervisors from Vassar House were also
out following the youth around. Supervisor Z said she did not think
to swap with a staff and send them out looking for the youth.
Supervisor Z said the last she saw the youth they were walking
into the woods in the dark and had sticks. Supervisor Z said she
does not think it was safe for any staff to follow the youth into the
woods due to not knowing what they had and being unable to see
due to the darkness. Supervisor Z said the police were contacted
that night however stated they would not be looking on the
property for the youth. Supervisor Z was not able to recall any
other staff working outside of Staff 5 that night.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Truancy Policy and Procedure
was reviewed. The policy states if “non-supervising staff is
available, they will walk with the client and continue to
provide verbal support and redirection encouraging the
client not to truant”. In addition, the policy states “Staff will
immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist Supervisor on
duty when line of sight is lost, no later than 15 from loss of
line of sight (when youth is determined AWOL).”
• Wolverine Human Services Line of Sight Policy was
reviewed. The policy states staff are to “maintain adequate
supervision coverage and “line of sight” of all clients when
in direct supervision of clients. Within the line of sight
means that it is possible to reasonably visually distinguish
and recognize individuals.”
• Wolverine Human Services Policy and Procedure for CPI in
Residential Programs. The policy outlines the expectations
for staff to intervene in “any behavior that is likely to result
in physical injury or imminent risk of physical harm of the
client, other clients, staff members, or others”.
• Youth C, Youth D and Youth E incident reports documenting
the refusal of medical treatment on August 28, 2024, after
the night of the AWOL was reviewed. Youth C, Youth D, and
Youth E were brought to the emergency room however
refused to wait to be seen by a physician.
• Clarence Fischer Center Incident reports for physical fights
between youth for the month of August 2024, were
reviewed. There were twenty total incident reports provided
and reviewed. All of the incident reports indicated how staff
intervened to prevent or stop the physical altercation
between youth. There is no information in any of the
incident reports that indicate staff did not respond
appropriately during each incident.
10

• Wolverine Human Services Incident Report for Youth F
dated August 29, 2024, was reviewed. The incident report
is consistent with Supervisor Y’s interview. In addition to the
incident report, the medical notes from Covenant
Healthcare dated August 29, 2024, were reviewed. The
medical notes indicated a “small hematoma to left
frontotemporal scalp with overlying abrasion”, and “right
hand x-ray showing no acute fracture”.
• Wolverine Human Services Incident reports for Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E dated August 28,
2024, were reviewed. The incident reports were all written
by Supervisor Z and reported all youth went AWOL from
their units on August 28, 2024, around 12:30am. The
incident reports are consistent with Supervisor Z’s
interview.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of August 16, 2024, unit four was viewed on
September 25, 2024. The video footage is of a physical altercation
between six youth. The youth are seen walking on and off the unit.
There were four staff present on the unit. The six youth are all
fighting one another at different time so when the staff stand in-
between two that are fighting, another group would begin to start
to fight with one another. The youth were swinging wildly at each
other and staff members stood in-between them. Supervisor Z is
present and is seen on her cell phone.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, review of incident reports, and review of video footage,
the staff at Clarence Fischer Center did everything they were
expected and could do to follow the youth that ran out of the units,
intervened in fights between youth, and provide for the protection
and safety of the youth at the facility.
Technical Assistance:
Technical Assistance was offered to review and update the
Wolverine Human Services Truancy Policy and Procedure to
provide direction and clarity to staff on what is expected of them
when they have safety concerns about following youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
11

Rule Code Staff to resident ratio
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
Description resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Facility is an unsafe environment. The ratio is off compromising
supervision and causing kitchen staff and other staff that don't
work with children to assist.
Investigation Interviews:
The complainant was anonymous.
Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Director said Clarence Fischer Center has
been scheduled to have enough staff to be in ratio and any time a
staff calls in or is running late staff are mandated to stay. Director
said all staff are trained to call a supervisor or coordinator if a
youth walks off the unit. Director said if the staff are able to follow
the youth, they are required to however they are not directed to
leave the unit out of ratio. Director said there have not been any
kitchen staff working directly with the youth. Director said the
maintenance staff assisted by providing supervision to youth at
Clarence Fisher Center. Director said the maintenance staff go
through the same training as the direct care staff.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
30, 2024, by MDHHS worker, and on September 6, 2024, via
phone by DCWL consultant and MDHHS worker. Youth A said
he is on a unit with three other youth and there are always two
staff present even throughout the night. Youth A was aware the
ratio is one staff for every two youth and reported they are always
within ratio.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 11, 2024. Youth B said he is placed on a unit with
three other youth. Youth B said there are always two staff working
during the day and one staff working at night. Youth B said
sometimes a when a youth runs off the unit the staff will follow and
leave one staff with three youth, other times the staff have brought
a youth with them when they follow the youth that runs out of the
unit. Youth B said he has never seen kitchen, maintenance, or
cleaning staff working his or any other unit. Youth B said the only
staff have worked with him were direct care staff.
12

Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Youth C said he is on a unit with two other
youth and there are always two staff members working with them.
Youth C said only youth specialists have worked with him at
Clarence Fischer Center.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
30, 2024, by MDHHS worker, and on September 6, 2024, via
phone by DCWL consultant and MDHHS worker. Youth D
reported there are three youth in the unit with him and two staff
work during the day and one staff work at night. Youth D said
sometimes at night there are two staff but not every night. Youth D
said the staff told him "they say they got 15 minutes to be out of
ratio by the policy, but they really don't be out of ratio." Youth D
said sometimes in the morning the staff will have them sleep in
longer because staff are late to work but that is not often. Youth D
denied any kitchen staff working on his unit.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 3, 2024. Youth E said he is on a unit with three other
youth and two staff are always supervising them. Youth E said he
does not know the title of the staff members that worked his unit
but stated they were “always different people”.
Youth F was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024. Youth F said the ratio is one staff for every
two youth during the day and one staff for every four youth at
nighttime. Youth F said there are four youth on his unit have
always had two staff working the unit. Youth F said there have
been times when a staff member has had to leave the unit to
follow a youth or help with other youth fighting which leaves one
staff with three youth, stating that has not happened in the last two
weeks. Youth F said there was never any kitchen staff working his
unit however Maintenance 1 staff has worked one time on their
unit within ratio. Youth F said all other staff that have worked his
unit have been direct care staff.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on October 24, 2024.
Staff 1 said he worked at Clarence Fischer Center for about six
months. Staff 1 said he does not recall any point when working out
of ratio.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on September 25, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 said she has never
been in a situation when she had to work out of the one to two
ratio, however noted there is a lot of people being mandated to
13

work or stay at work due to staff quitting or walking off in the
middle of their shifts. Staff 2 said when staff walk off, supervisors
have filled in and other staff are called in to work. Staff 2 said she
has never seen any kitchen or maintenance staff working on the
units at Clarence Fischer Center, it has always been youth
specialists. Staff 2 said she would bring youth with her to follow
the youth that walked out in order to stay within ratio, as there was
no extra staff working.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on September 30, 2024,
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 5 said she has
worked mainly third shift however has had to stay over and
worked first shift as well. Staff 5 said there have been several
times when she has been working out of ratio and will have four or
five youth with one staff when the ratio is supposed to be one staff
for two youth. Staff 5 was not able to recall exactly when these
situations occurred. Staff 5 denied working with staff from
maintenance or kitchen.
Supervisor Y was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024. Supervisor Y said the staff are always
scheduled to be in ratio and if someone calls in or no-shows the
staff on shift are mandated to stay and work. Supervisor Y said he
is not aware of times when they were out of ratio. Supervisor Y
said Maintenance 1 has assisted by picking up shifts on the units,
and Maintenance 2 has assisted with transporting youth as
needed.
Supervisor Z was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
September 18, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Supervisor Z said she never had any situations when staff were
working out of ratio, however noted “a lot of mandating” was
happening where staff were held over their shifts due to a lack of
staff coming into work. Supervisor Z said they were unable to staff
any extra staff on any shift and were working with the minimum
amount of staff to cover ratio. Supervisor Z said she has never
seen any maintenance staff, kitchen staff, or cleaning staff working
shifts.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Truancy Policy and Procedure
was reviewed. The policy states if “non-supervising staff is
available, they will walk with the client and continue to
provide verbal support and redirection encouraging the
client not to truant”. In addition, the policy states “Staff will
immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist Supervisor on
14

duty when line of sight is lost, no later than 15 from loss of
line of sight (when youth is determined AWOL).”
• Wolverine Human Services Line of Sight Policy was
reviewed. The policy states staff are to “maintain adequate
supervision coverage and “line of sight” of all clients when
in direct supervision of clients. Within the line of sight
means that it is possible to reasonably visually distinguish
and recognize individuals.”
• Maintenance 1 personnel file was reviewed. Maintenance 1
had the required clearances completed prior to hire and
participated in the appropriate training required to provide
supervision to youth.
• Maintenance 2 personnel file was reviewed. Maintenance 2
had the required clearances completed prior to hire and
participated in the appropriate training required to provide
supervision to youth.
• Clarence Fischer Center Staff Schedules for the month of
August 2024, and September 2024. The schedule
consistently had enough staff scheduled to cover the 1:2 or
1:4 ratios.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, and review of documentation, the staff were scheduled
to be in ratio and there is not enough information to support the
staff being out of ratio.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered to create a policy outlining
sleeping and awake hours to ensure clear ratio expectations.
Ratio is not to be contingent on when a staff arrive or leave work.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: An anonymous complaint alleged an unsafe environment at the Clarence Fischer Center, citing youth-on-youth assaults, potential weapon use, and a serious incident where multiple youths left their units unsupervised overnight. A thorough investigation involving interviews, document reviews, and video footage concluded that staff consistently intervened in fights, followed established protocols, and made reasonable efforts to supervise youths, leading to no substantiated violations. The report explicitly states 'No substantial violations were found' and places the facility in compliance with all rules, effectively clearing the facility and its staff of culpability for the alleged incidents.
